lot of what I do is either distinctly fantasy based or now you know
post-apocalyptic modern but something like an old wooden shack could live in
just about any world a fantasy setting can have an old trappers cabin or
something like that in the woods a modern setting could have an old
abandoned shack in the woods a futuristic setting could have an old
shack in the woods heck this will probably be able to be used for like a
Wild West setting it's pretty universal as long as I don't add any details that
are two distinct to a certain style so I'm gonna keep it as generic as possible

that's pretty easy only took me a few minutes for those of you who are super

let's check the walls I made about seven and a half inches long by three inches

real simple obviously same height to this point as
the walls I made these four and a half inches wide simple layout using a center

at the point here and make that peak you can do any angle you want but for simple
farmhouse kind of buildings I think a peak that has pretty much a right angle
is about what you want when you're doing something more fantasy in nature you
might want a sharper higher exaggerated peak but for something like this that's
just fine and I laid out one and literally just put it on top of another
piece of foam and cut it out with a knife this does not have to be perfect
now I just got to glue together this frame I'm gonna use hot glue because I
don't want to wait for PVA to dry and then after that it'll just be a matter
of ripping some XPS foam into thin sheets texturing it with a wire brush
and then cutting little strips of wood siding and gluing it to my frame

this parts going better than they thought okay that's all right now I have

I actually ended up staying awake really late last night until the base was

Podge to the top and also to the underside this edge here is plenty hard
it's going to be durable enough for my purposes and I'm not gonna add this to
another MDF base if this was the type of terrain that would be used at a club or
being thrown in a Rubbermaid bin and transported a lot I would feel less
comfortable with this edge but for me it's gonna sit on my shelf and then go
on the table and that's about it and it's gonna be good enough on this
particular project I actually decided to do a second coat of black Mod Podge
that's something I almost never do usually the single coat is enough and I
don't like putting on a second one because it can obscure some of the
details and things like woodgrain but this one I mean it's a pretty vulnerable
fragile little piece so I did double up and hopefully I didn't lose too much
detail but looking at it I think I'll be okay I also while doing that decided
that this part here where it was sunken down and crushed the door looked a
little bit weird so I quickly made some little pieces to look like the remnants
of the broken bottom side of the door now it's time to paint the
and generally if you've watched any of my other videos I've covered painting
old weathered wood numerous times and usually the way I approach it is a black
undercoat and then a thin coat of like a golden or light brown followed by a grey
weathering that creates a really good look for wood that has seen some time in
the element but this one I want it to look really really old so I'm not even
gonna bother with that brown undercoat I'm gonna go straight into gray because
this thing in my mind has been sitting for a very very very long time exposed
to the elements because there's so many finicky little bits and actually there's
inside here that I need to kind of paint out so that you don't see the you know
cardstock bottom I'm gonna use my airbrush for base coating this but of
course that's not required and usually I would actually just do this with a
paintbrush so let's spray this with some grey
[Applause]
this is the results of a very simple and easy paint job it was really quick to do
and actually probably took a lot longer for the washes to actually dry and then
it did to apply anything just a gray base coat a dry brushing of a suede
which is just a generic light tan and then a very light dry brushing of an
off-white or vanilla just simple cheap craft paints I followed that up by a
wash with my homemade black wash and my homemade brown wash recipes I'll put a
link up there for the video if you haven't seen that one and I kind of just
randomly mixed them together to give it a bit of variety to the tone and because
that created such a uniform sort of paint job I mean everything is just
weathered wood it was kind of monotone and boring so I needed something to give
it a little bit of variation so I went in with two Citadel washes the egg
cracks earth shade which is a brown and what I decided to do is use it
specifically on the shingles and kind of the framework around windows and doors
and this sort of gives it a bit of variation to look like maybe this is
slightly different wood than this and this but they're both very very
weathered the GW green wash I went in and I added a bit of you know kind of
green algae sort of moss enos to everything especially in the lower
recesses in corners and kind of streaked it across some of the seams and that
little bit of work there made this look a bit more dynamic and interesting now I
got to deal with this base now that everything else is done and I could just
paint it I definitely don't want to just flock it with grass I want this thing to
look like it is in the mud I will put some vegetation on it but I mostly want
it to look like it's in muddy earth rather than just painting it I think I'm
gonna go in with some Vallejo earth texture the reason I want to use this
stuff and again I put a link to the video where I reviewed
this stuff previously the reason I want to use this is that you will add a
little bit more grain to this most importantly this stuff drives really
hard almost like concrete it's gonna make this base just a little bit more
durable and you know I'll feel a little bit better about it now the problem is
that I have a couple colors here but none of them are the color that I really
want to use the black is just too black this stuff is jet black then I have this
stuff the dark earth it's a really good soil color it's kind of a brown sort of
grayish color it looks good but it's very similar to the color of this house
and I don't want it to just blend in with the wood then the next one I have
is this brown earth which is far too orange II to be appropriate I think it
would look really strange so what I'm gonna try to do here is I'm gonna mix
these two together and hopefully it will give me a darker reddish brown that I
can use you can tint this stuff with paint and I have some white that I could
use for that but I'm just gonna mix these two together and see what happens
still a little bit too peanut-buttery I really want this to be a bit darker so
I'm gonna try a bit of black ink that's about right stuff is nice because it's
basically a paint that you can sculpt with pretty good
here's the next challenge I have to
figure out I got these windows and these were glued right to the foam core so
they don't have holes in them they have a solid background and a lot of the time
I would have this cutaway and just have the frame there and then maybe use like
some UV resin or some plastic or something to create the windows but
because I don't have access to the inside of this and they don't really

for a typical window it would be really odd if this building being as
dilapidated and broken as it is had perfect panes of glass that weren't
broken so I need to put glass in them that is broken and rather than cutting
little pieces of plastic to try to do that I'm gonna try something here I'm
using my green stuff world UV resin and then see if I can damage them now I just
got a cure it with the UV light for about 30 seconds now my hope is that I
can cut and damage these and have it look good not bad and actually I can I
can peel it a bit too so I only let this resin cure for a very short period it's
not totally hard yet and I can easily cut through it and I'm not seeing it
look like any ugly unsightly foam core edges are showing through this is
actually working pretty good I like this this actually looks great
that's fantastic I'm gonna cure it a little bit more with some more UV light
and then I have some awesome broken windows
so what do you guys think let me know in
the comments section overall I'm pretty happy with how this little build turned

was that it could be used in any sort of setting and that it would be generic but
the more I worked on it the more I saw that it would actually be the best
suited for a one-shot survival horror game doesn't this thing just scream
Jason Voorhees murder shack be super fun to use this in a little Halloween
